Best scam I've ever seen:

1. Guy posts his MEW private key in a chat.
2. $5k worth of Minerium in it, no ETH for gas.
3. Half the people in the chat send gas to take it.
4. Smart contract. Auto-sends the $ETH to another address; keeps MNE in the account.

Fucking brilliant.

1110207843788091393.text:
I propose formalizing a mechanism for change, for any idea, no matter how much it makes us cringe.

In other words, a Constitution, and a formal process to amend it. 

The difficulty to amend reflects the currency’s ethos. Bitcoin: slow & steady. Ethereum: faster, experimental.

1110205334117851136.text:
The alternative, which we see in Bitcoin, is ad-hoc saying “no” whenever someone comes by with a new idea. The “gatekeeper” approach.

What happens when a *more* influential figure comes around and rallies enough folks to do something outside the spirit of Bitcoin?

1110204192768122880.text:
Why? The amount of cooperation needed to revoke an amendment is insurmountable. Incentives need to align at the state and federal level. 

But because there exists a well-defined path, those with radical new ideas follow it. People don’t walk through mud when a clear path exists!

1110203656392056832.text:
I contend that a well-defined mechanism for change better keeps Bitcoin immutable than ad-hoc swatting down ideas.

Case in point: there is a well-defined mechanism to nullify an amendment from the U.S. Constitution. Proposals to do so have had a success rate of 0.008%.

1058533975533203456.text:
There have been 11,699 proposed amendments to the Constitution.

Of those, only 27 made it in.

Of those, only 1 made it in that negated a previous amendment (the prohibition of alcohol). That’s a 0.008% success rate.

1058530976047996928.text:
To this effect, the pillars of this system — rooted in decentralization — cannot be changed by majority rule.

It requires: 
- A 2/3rds majority in both the House and Senate (different electorates)
- 38 of 50 states ratifying the amendment (different electorates AND incentives)

1058523980741664773.text:
Finally, and most importantly:

The Founding Fathers intentionally designed Congress to move extremely slowly. 

(This is a fact — you can look this up yourself.)

1058522913211666433.text:
Checks and balances prevent any one branch from growing too powerful.

The branch deciding on the constitutionality of laws has no authority to write laws. This is a dual-control. 

Congress and the executive branch rely on different electorates, and check one-another.

1058520512115195904.text: Federalism (the delegation of powers to states, when not explicitly granted to the central government) protects states from being overrun by an overly powerful central government.

1058519689268285448.text:

1006929192733245442.text:
#Ethereum Tip #3:  savings by using “external” over “public"

In #Solidity...

→ "External" functions are only callable OUTSIDE the contract. Arguments passed in the TX's calldata.

→ “Public" functions can also be called internally, so arguments must get copied to memory.

1006608085840953347.text:
The answer is no, it should not.

“Proper” use of SafeMath would mean that you have a require() checking for overflow/underflow before any call to SafeMath.

In other words, you check for overflow twice!

1006527545704157185.text:
The SafeMath library by OpenZeppelin uses "assert" instead of "revert"

But should it? 

If a user calls an "add" function in your contract, and that "add" causes an overflow, this is no fault of the sender. "Revert" should be used to return the remaining gas and take blame.pic.twitter.com/dd4RPO1RyD

1006521509412851713.text:
#Ethereum Tip #2: assert vs revert

 ASSERT
Burns remaining gas, produces invalid opcode.

 REVERT
Refunds remaining gas, compiles to revert.

The difference? BLAME! 
Assert assigns blame to the sender. “You sent malformed data!"
Revert assigns blame to the contract.

997095681423704064.text:
Where things get clever is when you find a way to make software run not as intended. 

- Code execution through DHCP
- Guest-to-host escape in a VM
- Etc.

But the vast majority of breaches don’t even need this.

997094185932066816.text:
If I send an email with an executable attached to it, and the recipient runs that executable, what happens?

The recipient’s computer works as intended. It runs the software the recipient told it to run.

And suddenly, I’m a hacker because of it.pic.twitter.com/x2Sy49kJ3i

997092195386757120.text:
If I phish someone’s credentials and use it to enter their company through their VPN, what’s happening?

The VPN software is working as expected. It just thinks I’m Jane Doe.

I’m a hacker for using the VPN as a different user.pic.twitter.com/v9YoIWO3fL

997091013570199553.text:
Hackers don’t really shoulder-surf. They do this over email.

But is this technical? 

Does this warrant a ton of hubris, and lines like “I owned that company” after an engagement?

997089203715485696.text:
If I work in IT, shoulder-surf you, and have you install Microsoft Word — am I a hacker?

Probably not. But replace Word with some arbitrary software I wrote.

The computer will do as it’s told by the software either way. But in example 2, I am suddenly a “hacker”.

997088397519925249.text:
The vast majority of “hacking” you see involves running software as it is intended to be run. Just as a different user.

A hacker runs software on someone else’s computer. It sounds less cool when you put it like that, doesn’t it?

958168894014918656.text: EthereumJ, on the other hand, does this the right way. The data used to initialize block 0 is all held in the "frontier.json" file. Every line in that file is data that gets fed into block 0 on your blockchain -- nothing else.pic.twitter.com/6nH7TZEciv

958168315121291264.text: Similarly, when you create a custom genesis.json file, you can stick the "config" struct right in the middle of data used to initialize block 0.pic.twitter.com/I6H9JEYJQr

958167983158853633.text: For example, in the photo I posted, you see the "config" variables -- which talk about forks way down the road, in the same "Genesis" struct as data that is actually used to initialize block 0 (the pre-sale allocations, the nonce, the mixHash, etc.)

958167543780401152.text: My criticism about Geth is that it conflates the idea of "genesis" by placing both the genesis block's data as well as general blockchain configuration variables together. EthereumJ does not do this.pic.twitter.com/f7bu6ikp1a
